title: 113_s1126
content: The "Prescribe A Book Act" establishes Pediatric Early Literacy Programs under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. It includes definitions related to pediatric involvement in reading and education. The "Prescribe A Book Act" defines an eligible entity as a nonprofit organization with demonstrated effectiveness in providing training on literacy promotion to healthcare providers, delivering training curriculum in various medical education settings, offering technical assistance for implementing Pediatric Early Literacy Programs, providing discounted books to healthcare facilities, and integrating developmental research into training. The "Pediatric Early Literacy Program" involves healthcare providers promoting early language and literacy by encouraging parents to read aloud to children, providing books to children aged 6 months to 5 years, and having volunteers offer books in waiting areas. The "Pediatric Early Literacy Program" involves volunteers in healthcare facilities reading aloud to children, demonstrating effectiveness in altering parent behavior and improving language skills in young children, and receiving endorsement from medical associations. The Secretary can award grants to eligible entities for Pediatric Early Literacy Programs. Eligible entities must submit an application and provide matching funds equal to at least 50% of the grant received. Grant funds must be used as specified. An eligible entity receiving a grant for a Pediatric Early Literacy Program must enter into contracts with private nonprofit organizations or public agencies, provide training and technical assistance to contractors, and include terms determined by the Secretary for program effectiveness. Contractors are selected based on prioritizing at-risk children, particularly those from low-income families in high-poverty areas. Children eligible for the Pediatric Early Literacy Program include those without adequate medical insurance, enrolled in Medicaid or CHIP, living in rural areas, migrant children, and those with limited library access. The Secretary must ensure that eligible entities in the Pediatric Early Literacy Program obtain books at discounted rates and report on program effectiveness annually. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act. The Pediatric Early Literacy Program includes definitions, program authorization, applications, matching requirements, use of grant funds, restrictions on payments, and reporting requirements. Eligible entities must obtain books at discounted rates and report on program effectiveness annually. A conforming amendment is made to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act.
